content: I'm happy to see this stream created, i've had it on my mind to come back to the conversation about how to sustain development on the reference.
(I was also wondering whether it should show up in the #t-lang > prioritization document...)
i.e., some kind of goal around "completeness" as something we are actively working towards
I think the biggest question is "personpower" -- who is going to organize and promote this

personally i think rust reference has a lot in common with rustc-dev-guide. If reference is work half-way towards language specification, then rustc-dev-guide is work half-way towards implementation specification :)
i mean, "reference implementation" specification, lol

If I knew how to organize this, I might be able to get the energy to actually do this. I've been floundering on what to do lately, so getting back to the Reference could be an energizing change of pace.
One thought I had is
well i've been thinking about lang team prioritization in general
and I think that it would be good to have some goals around the roadmap
but I've been a bit reluctant because I don't know want to commit people etc without an idea of how we'll achieve it
I wondered if a design meeting might be useful to discuss, but probably better to start async
what we've been doing in #wg-traits is taking a "sprint-like" approach, where we set some overall goals and then each 6 weeks we kind of outline some themes etc
I feel like it'd be helpful to talk about what a good "goal" for the reference is and what it would take to get there
it will take somebody who wants to put in some org. energy though
I know I cannot do that because of ETOOMANYTHINGS
it's not clear how much work it has to be I guess, doesn't have to be a breakneck pace

I'd really like to hear a bit on what kind of things would be useful to people working on the roadmap in terms of invlolvement from lang team. I imagine more active help on reviewing etc might be on the list...
/me feels guilty about some reference PRs he hasn't provided feedback on

Reviewers would be a good first step, since without reviews, things go nowhere. FWIW, I have context on all of the open PRs since I recently reviewed all of them. If any lang members want to help, I can provide some context on the existing PRs. I also have opinions about broader topics, such as the goals of the reference, if anyone wants to discuss that.
Start small, just pick one normative statement about the language to officially stabilize as being normative :P
Or simply just add three chapters called "Scope", "Conformance" and "Normative References" in the beginning of the reference. (Just joking).
